titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Arnold Rosin Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Nancy Lyon, Carol King, and Michael Lotstein and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:46

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of a journal (thirty-two volumes), a notebook, correspondence, photograph album, and printed material documenting Arnold Rosin's life in Paris since 1949. Photographs of Rosin's paintings are also included in the papers.

langmaterial.language: The materials are in primarily English, with some French.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Arnold Rosin Papers (MS 1475). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is arranged by accession.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Arnold Rosin was born in New Haven, Connecticut, in 1920. He studied painting and the history of art at the Yale University School of Art. During World War II, Rosin served in the Ninth Air Force in Europe as an intelligence officer and interpreter. In 1949 he returned to France, entered the Atelier Fernand Léger in Montmartre, and settled permanently in Paris. He participated in a number of exhibitions, including the Salon de Mai in 1952. His paintings are in private collections in the United States, England, France, Switzerland, and Italy. In addition to painting and translating, Rosin worked for UNESCO, the Council of Europe, Time-Life , Le Monde , and La Vie Française . For a time he was assistant to the European head of the International Refugee Committee. In his later life, he concentrated on writing and painting. Rosin was the author of The Age of Crisis (1962) and Comment ne pas écrire un roman , (circa 2012). Rosin died on August 15, 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of a journal (thirty-two volumes), a notebook, correspondence, photograph album, and printed material documenting Arnold Rosin's life in Paris since 1949. Photographs of Rosin's paintings are also included in the papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in this accession include inventories of paintings, auction and sale price information, and material on one-man show.

did.unittitle: Photographs and photocopies of artwork with related materials

odd.head: General
odd.p: Related materials include an inventory of paintings, auction and sale price information, and material on a solo exhibition of Rosin's work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of correspondence, a chronlogical summary of life events, journal pages, notes, and photographs of paintings by Rosin.

odd.p: List usually annotated with journal page references.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondents include Peggy Bernstein, Francoise Kostalany, Frederic Raphael, Joëlle Rouy, Jeffrey Simmons, and Jean-Michel Ulmann.

did.unittitle: Photographs of paintings, including paintings sold

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession includes both incoming and outgoing correspondence of Arnold Rosin, spanning 2013 and 2014, as well as photographs of several of his paintings dating from 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of Arnold Rosin's journal, dated June 7, 2014-June 7, 2015; chronological summary pages; philosophical and philological notes; copies of letters; a contract to translate "Le Grand Louvre"; a partial list of translations done by Rosin; and printed images of Rosin's paintings.

did.unittitle: Chronological summary of volume XXX, part 2 and volume XXXI, part 1, pages 146-150

odd.head: General
odd.p: Correpondents include Peggy Bernstein, Didier Bruner, Philippine Cruse, Philippe Fauvernier, Roger Grenier, Stéphane Maltère, Frederic Raphael, Pierre-Guillaume de Roux, Joëlle Rouy, Jrffrey Simmons, and Carolyn Williams.

scopecontent.p: Correspondents include Barbara Aycock, Frank Boivin, Jean-Jacques Faure, Joëlle Roy, John Rutherford, Amélie Sauvel, and U.S. Ambassador (invitation).
